none: Letter to Louis L. McInnis from Robert F. Smith, August 10, 1886
Letter to Louis L. McInnis from Robert F. Smith, August 10, 1886
Box 1 Louis L. McInnis Papers/Box 1 Folder 23 Louis L. McInnis Papers

en: A personal letter from Robert F. Smith to Professor Louis L. McInnis dated August 10, 1886 (though postmarked August 15), written from South Orange, New Jersey. Smith recounts his recent travels through various northeastern cities including Washington, Baltimore, and Philadelphia, and shares social greetings and invitations from mutual acquaintances including the Whitlock family. The letter indicates Smith's upcoming travel plans to Kentucky and Texas, and includes casual observations about leisure activities in the New York area.

body.value:
South Orange, N.J.
Aug. 15. 1886.

Dear Prof. McInnis;

I found your
letter waiting for me when I
got back from Asbury
Park last week. Was glad
to hear from you.

I had letters from Mrs.
Hardeman and Dr. Read.
Mrs. H. wrote that they had
had plenty of rain and
that the Generals crops were
turning out better than he
expected. I have been bum
ming round the country al-
most constantly since I
wrote you before. Dont re-
member whether or not I
had been to Washington

there. Spent three days there,
one day in Balt., four days
in Fredrich, Md, with a cous-
in who will accompany me
to Texas. Whitlock and I
spent several days in and
near Phila. I got home at
11:30 P.M. on Monday and H.
rushed in early Tuesday,
and told me I had just
twenty minutes to get my
valise packed to go to Ocean
Grove and Asbury Park.
Spent one week on that trip
and had a delightful trip
Spent yesterday forenoon
in Central Park (third day).
I expect to start to Ky. Sat.
and will be glad to hear
from you at Mt. Sterling, Ky
Expect to reach Hillsb, Tex
about 28th inst. Kindest
[Margin: regards to all]

**Analysis and Transcription of Handwritten Letter** Okay, so I've got this image of a handwritten letter here. It looks like it's a continuation, starting mid-thought, likely from a previous page. The handwriting is cursive, a bit faint in some places, but generally readable. There are some corrections and scribbles. My task is to transcribe this as accurately as possible, making sure to preserve the intended meaning of the author while honoring the visual form. First, I'll go line by line. I'm seeing: * "there. Spent three days there," * "one day in Balt., four days" – "Balt." probably means Baltimore. * "in Fredrich, Md, with a cous-" – Frederick, Maryland; the word "cousin" is split at the end of the line. * "in who will accompany me" – the word "cousin" carries onto this line. * "to Texas. Whitlock and I" * "spent several days in and" * "near Phila. I got home at" – "Phila" is Philadelphia. * "11:30 P.M. on [Tuesday crossed out] Monday and H." – "Tuesday" is crossed out, and "Monday" is written above; "H." is likely a person's initial. * "rushed in early Tuesday," * "and told me I had just" * "twenty minutes to get my" * "valise packed to go to Ocean" – "valise" is an older word for a suitcase. * "Grove and Asbury Park." * "Spent one week on that trip" * "and had a delightful trip" – I'm reading this as "delightful trip" * "Spent yesterday forenoon" * "in Central Park (third day)." * "I expect to start to Ky. Sat." – "Ky." is Kentucky, and "Sat." is Saturday. * "and will be glad to hear" * "from you at Mt. Sterling, Ky" * "Expect to reach Hillsb, Tex" – I think this is "Hillsboro, Texas." * "about 28th inst. Kindest" – "inst." means current month, and the "th" is superscript. Ah, and I see some marginalia! There's text written vertically along the right edge: "regards to all". Now, I'll refine the transcription. "Fredrich", I'm pretty sure that's a slightly misspelled "Frederick", but the writer wrote "Fredrich". The date, "28th", I'll represent that superscript. I'll need to remember to insert those HTML tags. The marginalia... "Kindest regards to all" makes sense. Now for formatting. I can't use `del` or `s` for strikethrough, so I'll need to carefully represent the correction for clarity. Given the constraints, I will prioritize the "Monday" from "11:30 P.M. on [Tuesday crossed out] Monday".

there. Spent three days there,
one day in Balt., four days
in Fredrich, Md, with a cous-
in who will accompany me
to Texas. Whitlock and I
spent several days in and
near Phila. I got home at
11:30 P.M. on Monday and H.
rushed in early Tuesday,
and told me I had just
twenty minutes to get my
valise packed to go to Ocean
Grove and Asbury Park.
Spent one week on that trip
and had a delightful trip
Spent yesterday forenoon
in Central Park (third day).
I expect to start to Ky. Sat.
and will be glad to hear
from you at Mt. Sterling, Ky
Expect to reach Hillsb, Tex
about 28th inst. Kindest
[Margin: regards to all]

I've got to double-check a few of those specifics. "Fredrich" is the written letter here. "Phila" is right. The "Hillsb, Tex" is "Hillsboro, Texas". The crucial edit, "11:30 P.M. on Monday and H.", I've represented it accurately as

to Mrs. McInnis and a
kiss for Miss McInnis.
The Whitlock family wish
to be kindly remembered to
all. Mrs. Whitlock says
she thinks it real mean
that Mrs. McInnis doesn't
write to her. Both Mrs. W.
and E. request me to ex
tend an invitation to
you to come out while
you are in New York.
Am going to see a
professional base ball
game this afternoon,
and to Coney Island
tonight. Tomorrow I
go to Brighton Beach to
see the races. The con-
clusion of this letter is
almost as long as the
body of it. Yours very truly
[Signature] Robt S. Peck.

**My Transcription Journey: A Handwritten Letter Unveiled** Alright, let's dive into this image and get a clear transcription. This looks like the tail end of a letter, likely from the late 19th or early 20th century, with that familiar cursive script. The ink's a bit faded, but the words are definitely legible. First, I need to get the layout and overall structure right. I'll start line by line and try to maintain the rhythm and flow of the text. * **Line 1:** "to Mrs. McInnis and a" – The name "McInnis" is where I start. There is a dot, the 'i', so 'McInnis'. * **Line 2:** "kiss for Miss McInnis." – Yep, confirming it's McInnis again. * **Line 3:** "The Whitlock family wish" – "Whitlock" is clear as day. * **Line 4:** "to be kindly remembered to" * **Line 5:** "all. Mrs. Whitlock says" * **Line 6:** "she thinks it real mean" – It's colloquial, so let's preserve it. * **Line 7:** "that Mrs. McInnis doesn't" – There's an implied apostrophe. * **Line 8:** "write to her. Both Mrs. W." – "Mrs. W." – Got it. * **Line 9:** "and E. request me to ex" – Who's "E."? I wonder if it could be I. No. It looks like "E". "ex" at the end of the line, that’s clearly part of the following word. * **Line 10:** "tend an invitation to" – "ex tend." * **Line 11:** "you to come out while" * **Line 12:** "you are in New York." – "New York" is easy. * **Line 13:** "Am going to see a" * **Line 14:** "professional base ball" – Two words there: "base ball". * **Line 15:** "game this afternoon," * **Line 16:** "and to Coney Island" – "Coney Island". * **Line 17:** "tonight. Tomorrow I" * **Line 18:** "go to Brighton Beach to" – "Brighton Beach". * **Line 19:** "see the races. The con-" – Hyphenated at the end: "con-". * **Line 20:** "clusion of this letter is" * **Line 21:** "almost as long as the" * **Line 22:** "body of it. Yours very truly" * **Line 23:** "[Signature]" – The signature is the biggest puzzle. * "Robt". "Robt" seems correct. * The middle initial... It looks like 'P', no wait, it looks like 'S', it looks like a cursive 'S', and 'S' is a common letter. So, "Robt S. ...". * Now, the last name. The letter after initial is really sharp and pointy, so it's not 'e'. It could be "P" then "r" but is that a dot above it? That looks like an 'i'. Does it end in k? Looks like it! "Peck"? I will stick with that name unless there is some compelling reason to change it. Now, it looks like I need to write 'S' again. So, the final transcription is:

to Mrs. McInnis and a
kiss for Miss McInnis.
The Whitlock family wish
to be kindly remembered to
all. Mrs. Whitlock says
she thinks it real mean
that Mrs. McInnis doesn't
write to her. Both Mrs. W.
and E. request me to ex
tend an invitation to
you to come out while
you are in New York.
Am going to see a
professional base ball
game this afternoon,
and to Coney Island
tonight. Tomorrow I
go to Brighton Beach to
